title: Integration Studio—Service Manager to Service Management data import
content:
The Integration Studio provides a capability to move data from Service Manager to Service Management. A set of templates are also available to ease the data import from Service Manager to the corresponding Service Management record types. 


This capability is not designed for the migration of a Service Manager system to Service Management. You can use it only for demonstration purposes and only for partial data import.
The scenario templates used in this integration don't import attachments or pictures embedded in Service Manager records, with the exception for knowledge articles. If you want to retain attachments in other imported records, add attachment retrieval rules to the scenario. For details, see How to upload attachments.
The integration use cases described in this document serve as examples to inspire and guide your integration efforts. However, they should not be considered as prescriptive or guaranteed solutions for your particular scenario. The examples may or may not be applicable for your license edition.


Overview

This capability supports data import for certain objects or record types, and has product version requirements.

    Supported objects or record types

    The capability supports the following objects or record types.

    Supported versions

    Service Manager codeless 9.40 or later (non-Process Designer environments may work but haven't been tested and may require scenario changes) 

    Before you start

    Before you start, pay attention to the following. 

    Product knowledge and skills

    Ensure you have experience in the following technological areas to successfully use the provided solution. 

    Service Manager  

    • The database structure, especially for the objects to migrate from Service Manager to Service Management 
    • The REST API and the Web Service Configuration area of Service Manager 
    • The Unload Manager to unload data from Service Manager 

    Service Management 

    • The Studio, especially how to manage the database attributes in the records section and the forms
    • The Service Management database structure, especially the ENTITY_LINKS between database entities 
    • The Lists feature (ENUM) to find the correct values for drop-down lists 
    • The EMS REST APIs and Manage Persons API
    • The Integration Studio 

    Network connectivity 

    To connect from Service Management to Service Manager, use one of the following options:

    • Option 1 (recommended): Run Service Management and Service Manager in the same network to directly connect the two systems. 
    • Option 2: Use the On-Premises Bridge agent to connect the two systems. For example, from a Service Management SaaS environment to a Service Manager system in the customer's data center. 

    SaaS 

    If Service Management  is running on SaaS, you can choose either way:

    • Connect Service Management to a Service Manager instance provided by the SaaS Operations team. Your Service Manager data is then uploaded into this Service Manager instance. 
    • Install the On-Premises Bridge Agent in your data center to directly connect Service Management  with your Service Manager system. 

    Cloud or on-premises 

    If Service Management is running in a cloud or on-premises environment, the connectivity depends on your network settings. If an HTTP connection can be established between the two systems, you can use the solution directly. If not, consider using the On-Premises Bridge Agent. 

    Prepare Service Manager

    Prepare your Service Manager system as follows.

    Configure Service Manager Web Services 

    To ensure the required Web Service Definitions are in place, load the “xie_webservices.unl” file. This will load the following Webservice definitions, which the Integration Studio is relying on, into the Service Manager system. 

    This unload file will add the following Webservice definitions.

    If HTTPS is used to connect to the Service Manager REST API, only one-way SSL is supported. For more information, see Configure one-way SSL.

    Prepare data for the Service Manager instance

    If Service Management can't directly connect to your Service Manager instance, you need to provide the data in unload files, and then load them into a local Service Manager instance that Service Management can connect to. 

    The solution supports the import from the following Service Manager objects:  

    • Locations 
    • Departments 
    • Assignment Groups 
    • Category, Subcategory, Product-Types 
    • Devices (type bizservice or type computer) 
    • Operators and Contacts 
    • Knowledge Documents 
    • Service Catalog 
    • Interactions incl. Activities of the Interaction 
    • Incident incl. Activities of the Incident 
    • Change Model 
    • Changes (including Activities of the Changes)
     
    • You must package Categories, Subcategories, and Product-Types together.
    • You must package Operator and Contact data together.  
    To avoid large unload files, we recommend that you unload the data per DBDICT and provide as much data as possible via unload files from those Service Manager objects. For details about how to unload data from Service Manager, see  Unload script utility.

    Prepare Service Management 

    To import the data from Service Manager into Service Management , perform the following steps. 

    Prepare an integration user for your Service Management tenant

    Perform the following steps to prepare an integration user:

    1. Create an integration user. See How to create an integration user. 
    2. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin, and assign the Tenant Admin role to the new integration user. 

    Export the certificates of the two systems

    For Service Management and Service Manager to connect with each other, you'll need the Service Manager certificate or need the certificates of both sides, in PEM format:

    • If not using the OPB Agent, you need the Service Manager root CA certificate. This is required only when Service Manager is using HTTPS. 
    • If using the OPB Agent, you need the certificates of both systems. You'll need to import them into the OPB agent.

    To export the certificate of the Service Management system:

    1. Open the Service Management tenant URL in a web browser.
    2. Export the root CA certificate to a file in base-64 encoded X.509 format (for example, smax_CA.cer). 

    For Service Manager, ask your Service Manager system administrator for the root CA file (for example, sm_CA.cer) of the Service Manager server. If using the Service Manager instance provided by SaaS Operations, contact SaaS Operations for the certificate.

    Download and install the OPB Agent if needed

    If the Service Management system can directly connect to the Service Manager system, there's no need to use the On-Premises Bridge (OPB) agent. If there's a web application firewall between the two systems, you need to use the OPB agent. An example is that Service Management is running on a public cloud and Service Manager is running in an on-premises environment. 

    To use the OPB Agent for the integration, perform the following steps. If you have already installed the OPB Agent and connected to Service Management, skip steps 1 and 2.

    1. In Service Management, download and install the OPB agent. Use the previously created integration user to install the OPB Agent, and you need to assign the integration user the OPB Remote Agent role. 
    2. Import the CA certificates of the Service Management system into the OPB agent's trusted keystore.
    3. Import the CA certificates of the Service Manager server into the OPB agent's trusted keystore. 
    4. In Service Management, add an agent. You will need to specify this agent when creating an endpoint for Service Manager. 
    5. In the Endpoint Credentials Manager, create a credentials record for the endpoint with the Rest Executor Domain 2.0 endpoint type. The credentials record must use a Service Manager user that has the “SysAdmin” and "RESTful API" capability words (for example, falcon). 

    For details, see How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Windows or How to use On-Premises Bridge agents on Linux. 

    Create an endpoint 

    Create an endpoint using the Rest Executor 2.0 endpoint type: 

    1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
    2. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Endpoints.
    3. Click Add.
    4. Select Rest Executor 2.0 as the endpoint type, enter a name for the endpoint (for example, MySM), and then click Add. The system creates the endpoint.
    5. Click Configure and complete the fields depending on whether the endpoint needs to use the OPB Agent. 
      If the endpoint doesn't need to use the OPB Agent, complete these fields. 
      Field Value 
      Agent Select Agentless.
      Authentication type Select Basic Authentication. 
      Protocol Select https. 
      Base URL Enter the base URL of the Service Manager System: https://<FQDN>:port. For example: https://mysmserver.mycorp.com:13443. 
      Username Enter the username of a Service Manager user. This user is used to connect to Service Manager. 
       This user must have the “SysAdmin” and "RESTful API" capability words. 
      Password Enter the password of the Service Manager user. 
      Confirm password Re-enter the password. 
      Certificate type  (only when https is used) Select X.509. 
      Certificate format  (only when https is used) Select PEM. 
      Server certificate  (only when https is used) 

      Copy the content of the Service Manager CA certificate into this field. 
      If using the Service Manager instance provided by SaaS Operations, contact SaaS Operations for the certificate.

      If the endpoint needs to use the OPB Agent, complete these fields. 
      Field Value 
      Agent Select the OPB agent that you have created.
      Authentication type Select Basic Authentication. 
      Protocol Select https. 
      Base URL Enter the base URL of the Service Manager system: https://<FQDN>:port. For example: https://mysmserver.mycorp.com:13443. 
      CredentialsSelect the credentials record that you've created for the endpoint in the Endpoint Credentials Manager. 

    Create an integration

    To create an integration: 

    1. Navigate to Administration > Utilities > Integration > Integration Studio.
    2. Click New, enter the name of your integration, and then click Save. The system displays the Integration page.
    3. In the Details section, configure the integration user you created for the current Service Management system and activate the integration.
    4. In the Connector-Endpoint mappings section, click Add to add a mapping.
    5. Select ServiceManager (under OpenText) as the connector, select the Service Manager endpoint that you created earlier, and then enter an alias for the mapping.
    6. Click Save.  

    Configure the scenarios

    Use the following out-of-the-box scenarios for this integration. The following table describes the actions required for each of the scenarios before you start an import. 

    Scenario nameActions required before starting an import 
    1 Import Locations None 

    2 Import Departments

    		None 
    3 Import Assignment GroupsNone 
    4 Import Categories, Subcategories, Areas None 
    5 Import Operator, Contacts In the Parameters rule at the start of the process logic, enter the License Name and License capacity. Decide which type of UPN to use. See below for more details. 
    6 Import Services, Computers None
    7 Import Knowledge Documents(Optional) In the Parameters rule at the start of the process logic, enter the valid record ID from a Service Management person record. This person is set in the “Created by” field. See below for more details. 
    8 Import Service CatalogNone 

    09 Import Interactions 

    In the Default Parameters rule, add the record IDs of a default Service, default Group, and default User.  

    10 Import Incidents 

    In the Default Parameters rule, add the record IDs of a default Service, default Group, and default User. 

    11 Import Change models 

    None 

    12 Import Changes 

    In the Default Parameters rule, add the record IDs of a default Service, default Group, and default Change Model. 

    Perform the following steps to add the scenarios to the integration:

    1. Click Add scenario. 
    2. Enter a name for the scenario. For example, enter 1 Import Locations.
    3. In the Template field, select 1 Import Locations (under OpenText Service Manager) from the list. 
    4. Click Save to add the scenario. 
    5. Repeat the steps above to add the rest of the scenarios listed in the table above, in the order they're listed. 
    The scenarios are defined and tested with an out-of-the-box Service Manager system. If your system is heavily customized, you may want to review and adjust the scenarios first. 

    Most of the scenarios are pre-configured and you can directly run them without the need for any modifications, but some require you to provide additional input before running them. 

    For example, to configure the required parameters for the Operator / Contact import, click the “5 Import Operator, Contacts” scenario in the left-side pane. In the main screen, expand the Parameters rule and enter your details in the “value” column. Don’t change the content in the “key” column. 

    keyvalue
    LicenseCapacity'5'
    LicenseName'Express edition concurrent user'
    UpnDataType'Email'

    Run the data import

    Now, your integration and scenarios are ready. For each scenario, the system automatically populates the Direction field with a value of Inbound and a Run scenario button is available for each inbound scenario. 

    Run the scenarios one by one in the following order, by clicking the Run scenario button: 

    1. Import Locations 
    2. Import Departments 
    3. Import Assignment Groups 
    4. Import Categories, Subcategories, Areas 
    5. Import Operator, Contacts 
    6. Import Services, Computers 
    7. Import Knowledge Documents 
    8. Import Service Catalog 
    9. Import Interactions 
    10. Import Incidents 
    11. Import Change Models 
    12. Import Changes 

    To ensure the references between records are correctly set, run the next scenario only when the current scenario has finished running.   

    Some record types, where cross-reference data is required, may have to be imported more than once to correctly set all related data. 

    How the solution works

    Each scenario in this solution follows the same process logic. This section explains this process logic and more details of each pre-configured scenario. 

    Process logic of a scenario

    Each scenario follows the same process: 

    1. Gets data from Service Manager
    2. Iterates through the data:
      1. Prepares the data as required in Service Management 
      2. Creates or updates the record in Service Management 

    The following figure shows an example. 

    Get data from Service Manager

    To get data from Service Manager, click the Add rule button. Select the Get Record(s) action from the target Service Manager. The rule is now added to the scenario.

    Now, configure the input parameters of the new rule:

    • Input - Collection Name: The Resource Collection Name from the Web Service definition in Service Manager. See the screenshot below for an example. 
    • Input - Query: The native Service Manager query.
    • Input - Sort Field: The field to sort the query results.
    • Input - Sort Order: The sort order
    • Input - Start: The first record to process. 
    • Input - Count: The number of records to fetch in one request.
    • Output – ReturnCode: You can define the output based on your needs. In these scenarios, the solution always parses the ReturnCode and the content of the response from Service Manager. If the ReturnCode is 0 (success), the solution starts the next rule in the process.

    Example:

    Get additional data from Service Manager

    The data returned by the REST call is defined in the Web Service Definition in Service Manager. To get data from additional fields, simply add those fields to the Web Service Definition for your object. Once an additional field is part of the Service Manager web service, you can use the field in the scenario like the pre-configured fields.
    The following figure shows an example field list.

    If a field doesn't contain data in the Service Manager record, it's not exposed in the REST response.

    Process the Service Manager response

    Once a “get request” succeeds, Service Manager returns an array with one or more records. The iterator rule can loop through an array to process each record of the array.
    Suppose you get the following response from Service Manager:

    {
    "@count": 6,
    "@start": 1,
    "@totalcount": 6,
    "Messages": [],
    "ResourceName": "XIELocation",
    "ReturnCode": 0,
    "content": [
        {
            "XIELocation": {
                "Address": [
                    "15 Van Der Graaff Rd"
                ],
                "City": "Cape Town",
                "Company": "advantage",
                "Country": "South Africa",
                "Email": "support@advantage-africa.com",
                "LastUpdate": "2008-06-02T15:01:06+00:00",
                "Location": "Africa",
                "LocationClosingTime": "17H0M0S",
                "LocationCode": "advantageafrica",
                "LocationFullName": "advantage/Africa",
                "LocationName": "advantage Africa",
                "LocationOpenTime": "9H0M0S",
                "LocationStructure": "Africa",
                "Phone": "082 82 34501",
                "SiteCategory": "B",
                "Zip": "7441"
            }
        },
        {
            "XIELocation": {
                "Address": [
                    "2729 Hunan Road"
                ],
                "City": "Shanghai",
                "Company": "advantage",
                "Country": "China",
                "Email": "support@advantage-asia.com",
                "LastUpdate": "2021-11-29T17:06:20+00:00",
                "Location": "Asia",
                "LocationClosingTime": "17H0M0S",
                "LocationCode": "advantageasia",
                "LocationFullName": "advantage/Asia",
                "LocationName": "advantage Asia",
                "LocationOpenTime": "9H0M0S",
                "LocationStructure": "Asia",
                "Phone": "0621 - 6268 9055",
                "SiteCategory": "B",
                "Zip": "200041"
            }
        }
    ]
}

    The key “content” contains all data. Each record's parent key name is “XIELocation”. The output of the first rule “Get Locations” parses the “content” key from the response JSON into the “Locations” parameter. 

    The iterator uses the “Locations" output parameter as input.

    Within the iterator rule, you can reference each element in the array with the keyword “item”. For example, “item.XIELocation.City” would extract “Cape Town” in the first iteration and “Shanghai” in the second iteration.

    The “Prepare Data” rule returns the “Data” object, with the configured elements.

    Create or update records in Service Management 

    Now,  the data is prepared, so the scenario can create or update a record in Service Management. Before that, the scenario checks if the record already exists. You can find the reconciliation key in the detailed scenario explanation. 

    Example:

    This rule returns two output parameter values:

    • Whether the record exists: yes or no
    • The record Id

    To create or update a record, the scenario uses the “Manage Record (EMS)” action from Service Management. You can use this action against any entity from the Service Management Studio. 
    To build the required payload, the scenario uses the content of “Data” object from the “Prepare Data” rule. In the “Operation” property, it uses the output of the previous rule to decide whether to create or update the record.

    Some scenarios are more complex than others, but the logic is always the same.

    Details of pre-configured scenarios

    This section explains the details of each pre-configured scenario.

    Locations

    The location import is managed in the scenario “1 Import Locations”.

    The following properties are special and therefore highlighted here. 

    PropertyNotes
    Id
    • Not required when creating a record.
    • Required when updating a record
    CodeThis field is populated with the SM key (LocationCode) and is used as the reconciliation key.

    What isn't imported:

    • The location hierarchy
    • The supervisor

    Departments

    The department import is managed in the scenario “2 Import Departments”. SM Department data is converted to organizational groups in Service Management. The department hierarchy from Service Manager is not kept. 

    The following properties are special and therefore highlighted here. 

    PropertyNotes
    Id
    • Not required when creating a record.
    • Required when updating a record
    UpnThis field is populated with the SM unique key (dept), and is used as the reconciliation key.
    AssignmentStrategy

    All organization groups are set to “None". 

    This value is an item from a Service Management List named “AssignmentStrategyEnum”.

    GroupType 

    All organization groups are set to “Organizational". 

    This value is an item from a Service Management List named “GroupType”.

    OwnershipSet to “Internal”.
    This value is an item from a Service Management List named “OwnershipEnum”.
    StatusSet to “Active”.
    This value is an item from a Service Management List named “GroupStatusEnum”.

    What isn't imported:

    • The department hierarchy. Each department is migrated; however, the parent/child relationship are not imported.
    • The SLA information from the Service Manager department record.
    • The Subscription information from the department.

    Assignment Groups

    The assignment group import is managed in the scenario “3 Import Assignment Groups”. A Service Manager Assignment Group is converted to a functional group in Service Management. 
    The following properties are special and therefore highlighted here. 

    PropertyNotes
    Id
    • Not required when creating a record.
    • Required when updating a record
    UpnThis field is populated with the SM unique key (name), and is used as the reconciliation key.
    AssignmentStrategy All organization groups are set to “None". 
    This value is an item from a Service Management List named “AssignmentStrategyEnum”.
    GroupType

     All assignment groups are set to “Functional". 

    This value is an item from a Service Management List named “GroupType”.

    Ownership  Set to “Internal”.
    This value is an item from a Service Management List named “OwnershipEnum”.
    Status Set to “Active”.
    This value is an item from a Service Management List named “GroupStatusEnum”.

    What isn't imported:

    • Coordinators
    • Manager
    • Alerts
    • Calendars and time zone
    • Group members (imported via the Operator import)

    Categories, Subcategories, Areas

    This scenario imports data from the Service Manager “Category, Subcategory and Producttype” tables and moves the data into the “ITProcessCategory” record type in Service Management. Service Management supports only a 3-level hierarchy, hence only those three category types are moved into Service Management.
    The following properties are special and therefore highlighted here. 

    PropertyNotes
    Id
    • Not required when creating a record.
    • Required when updating a record
    NameThis field is populated with the SM unique key (name), and is used as the reconciliation key.

    What isn't imported:

    • Alerts
    • Assignment Groups
    • Approvals

    Operators / Contacts

    The scenario with the name “5 Import Operators, Contacts” will handle the import of the person/user data into Service Management. This scenario is a little different than the others, because it merges data from the operator and contact record from Service Manager into one person record in Service Management.
    To do this, the scenario queries the contact record associated with the operator record and prepares the data accordingly.

    1. Get the operator
    2. Get the contact based on the operator
    3. Prepare the contact data
    4. Prepare the operator data
    5. Use the prepared data to create or update the person record in Service Management.

    Example:

    To use this scenario, you must configure the Parameters rule. Without having at least the correct license data set, the import will fail.

    You can find the license details in an existing Service Management user.

    The UpnDataType parameter specifies which login name is used. The standard value is “Email”. If you set the value to “Customer_UID,” you can set a login name other than email in the Upn property.
    When the import is triggered, the Manage Person API is managing the operation (Create or Update) to be executed against the Service Management. The Manage Person API checks the UPN in the Person record type to see if the record exists. For a full overview of the Person API, see Manage Persons API.
    During the import, Service Management creates a unique JOB ID for each imported Person record. This JOB ID represents that record uniquely and can return the status of the import job. This means importing persons via the Manage Person API is an asynchronous import process. The JOB ID is currently printed to the log file only.

    PropertyNotes
    UPNThis field is the Unique Key for all Person records. When the Manage Person API finds a user with an existing UPN, it updates the record is updated; otherwise,
    it creates the record.
    IsMaasUser    

    Service Management differentiates between users and contacts. Users can have roles and functional groups and require a license.
    Contacts are Person records, which might be used for references in Service Management records. Contacts can be assigned to organizational but not functional groups.
    They don't require a role or a license.

    To create a contact, you must set the IsMaasUser flag to false when sending the payload.

    Location

    Pass the Name value of each Location record in Service Management (example name: FM Storage). The API will calculate the location Id automatically to create a valid reference.

    Groups

    The system allows you to set only one Organizational Group. Only users can have an organizational group.
    A user can have many Functional Groups. However, currently, the solution support to only set ONE group.

    To have the relationships properly created, the group name must be the UPN of the group in Service Management.

    LicensesThe license data must match the licenses you generated for your system. The capacity and name must match; otherwise, the import will fail.
    This data is managed in the Parameters section.
    Roles

    The scenario is configured as such that a Service Manager self-service user gets the Self Service Portal user role in Service Management, and
    all other Service Manager users get the Tenant Admin role in Service Management.

    Only one role is supported in the current release. 

    To assign roles successfully, you must use the role names as displayed in Service Management. For example, Application Analyst. 

    The following roles are different from the display label. Use the names for those roles as documented here:

    Name                           DisplayLabel
    FavoritesAdminRole = Favorite Views Owner
    MTAdministrator      = MT Administrator
    MTAgent                  = MT Agent
    tenantAdmin            = Tenant Admin Role

    What isn't imported:

    • The roles of the user. 
    • Manager information
    • Subscriptions

    Services / Computers 

    This scenario imports CIs of type “bizservice” and “computer” into Service Management. Records of type “bizservice” will create an Infrastructure Service in the Actual Service record type in Service Management. Records of type computer will create records in the Device record type in Service Management.

    The following properties are special and therefore highlighted here. 

    PropertyNotes
    Id
    • Not required when creating a record.
    • Required when updating a record
    DisplayLabel This field is populated with the Service Manager display name field and is used as the reconciliation key for Actual Services.
    HostNameThis field is populated with the Service Manager display name field and is used as the reconciliation key for Devices.
    BusinessCriticality

    For Actual Services only:
    The mapping converts the priority of a service to the business criticality in Service Management. 

    SupportLevel1GroupThis field is set to the config admin group from Service Manager. The group must exist in Service Management to set it correctly.
       
    Environment This field has a mapping to convert Service Manager environments to Service Management ones.
    SubType

    This field has a mapping to convert the Service Manager Subtype to the Service Management Subtype.

    PhaseId

    The Service Management's PhaseId is set based on the status of the record in Service Manager. 

    What isn't imported:

    • Technical Details 
    • CI relationships
    • Support groups

    Knowledge Documents 

    This scenario imports knowledge documents from Service Manager and creates either Articles or News in Service Management. A News record is created when the “Hotnews” checkbox in Service Manager is set. All other documents are created as Articles.
    You can optionally set some parameters in the Parameters rule before running the scenario. For example, enter the record id from a Service Management person, in case you dont want to use the integration users record id. This parameter is used to set the “CreatedBy” property of the Knowledge Article in Service Management.

    The following properties are special and therefore highlighted here. 

    PropertyNotes
    Id
    • Not required when creating a record.
    • Required when updating a record
    ExternalId  This field is populated with the Id of the Knowledge Document in Service Manager and is used as the reconciliation key.
     
    PhaseId  

    Imported documents are moved to the state as in Service Manager. A mapping is implemented to set the proper phase in Service Management.

    What isn't imported:

    • Knowledge Categories
    • Related KM Docs
    • Services

    Service Catalog 

    This scenario imports Service Catalog categories and items from Service Manager into Service Management. Since the Service Manager catalog structure can have an unlimited number of layers and Service Management has a 3-layer structure, the templates have the following concept implemented.

    This means if items have more than 3 parent categories in the hierarchy, the provided templates can't import the data correctly. Catalog items are most likely imported into Service Management; however, the link to the Service Definition is probably missing.
    What isn't imported:

    • Access Filters
    • User Options
    • Embedded pictures, Attachments
    • Fulfillment Plans
    • Approvals
    • Owner Group
    • Prices

    Interactions

    This scenario imports Service Manager interactions and creates requests in Service Management. The scenario is trying to find the following data in Service Management to set the fields correctly. 

    • Requested By 
    • Service
    • Assignment Group 

    If the Service Manager data for those fields can't be found, the default values from the parameter rule are used. 

    To use this scenario, configure the Default parameters rule and set a record Id for the Service, User, and Group fields. 

    To differentiate between Service and Support requests, the scenario is trying to find the Service Management Service Catalog offering linked with the Interaction in Service Manager. If the offering is found in Service Management, the new request is linked with the Service Management offering and a Service request is created; if not, a Support request is created. This logic is implemented in the following rules in the scenario: 

    • Service Manager: Get Service Catalog item name
    • Service Management: Get record ID of the Offering

    The last rule in the scenario imports the activities of each interaction record into the Service Management discussion area. 

    The following attributes are special and are therefore highlighted here.

    Attribute 

    Comment 

    Id 

    Not required when creating a record

    Required when updating a record

    ExternalProcessReference 

    This field is populated with the Service Manager interaction ID and is used as a reconciliation key. 

    What isn't imported: 

    • Related records
    • SLAs 
    • Attachments 
    • Journal 

    Incidents

    This scenario imports Service Manager incidents and creates incidents in Service Management. The scenario is trying to find the following data in Service Management to set the fields correctly. 

    • Requested By 
    • Service 
    • Assignment Group 

    If the Service Manager data for those fields can't be found, the default values from the parameter rule are used. 

    To use this scenario, configure the Default parameters rule and set the record Id for the Service, User, and Group fields. 

    The last rule in the scenario imports the activities of each incident record into the Service Management discussion area. 

    The following attributes are special and are therefore highlighted here.

    Attribute 

    Comment 

    Id 

    Not required when creating a record

    Required when updating a record

    ExternalProcessReference 

    This field is populated with the Service Manager incident ID and is used as a reconciliation key. 

    What isn't imported: 

    • Related records 
    • SLAs 
    • Attachments 
    • Journal 
    • Parent Incidents logic 
    • Tasks 
    • Costs 

    Change models

    This scenario imports Service Manager Change Model records into Service Management. As part of the import, only the following fields are imported: 

    • Title 
    • Description 
    • Service 
    • Change type (Category in Service Manager) 

    The following attributes are special and are therefore highlighted here.

    Attribute 

    Comment 

    Id 

    Not required when creating a record

    Required when updating a record

    DisplayLabel 

    This field is populated with the Service Manager Change Model name and is used as a reconciliation key. 

    What isn't imported: 

    • Templates 
    • Task plans 
    • Subcategory 
    • Wizards 

    Changes

    This scenario imports Service Manager change records and creates change records in Service Management. The scenario is trying to find the following data in Service Management to set the fields correctly:

    • Requested By 
    • Service 
    • Assignment Group 

    If the Service Manager data for those fields can't be found, the default values from the parameter rule are used. 

    To use this scenario, configure the Default parameters rule and set the record Id for the Service, User, and Change Model fields. 

    The last rule in the scenario imports the activities of each change record into the Service Management discussion area. 

    The following attributes are special and are therefore highlighted here.

    Attribute 

    Comment 

    Id 

    Not required when creating a record

    Required when updating a record

    ExternalProcessReference 

    This field is populated with the Service Manager change ID and is used as a reconciliation key. 

    What isn't imported: 

    • Related records 
    • SLAs 
    • Attachments 
    • Journal 
    • Parent Incidents logic 
    • Tasks 
    • Costs 
    • Timestamps like “Scheduled date” 
    • Affected Configuration items 
    • CI attributes under change control
